Well, since you said currently, you obviously don’t mean in the past, although some past totalitarian nations have been the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany. Today, though, there are only three as far as I know: Iraq, China and North Korea. North Korea is clearly a totalitarian nation, as you hear from the media. The government has absolute power and the people aren’t allowed their own views, sometimes on pain of death. However, one thing should be made clear; there are NO stereotypes. Just because I said “absolute power”, does not make it “unquestioned power”. To think that people have whole different brains (almost like a second species) is nothing but racist. The people there are the same as you or I, but they are just accustomed to their particular way of life. As for China, it may not be the thing that comes to mind when somebody says the word. With that said, the definition of totalitarianism is, relating to a system of government that is centralized and dictatorial and requires complete subservience to the state (Google Dictionary). Now that you know that, you can see how China is totalitarian. It may not be as profound as North Korea, but it is a communist country officially. This, on our world, means that the government knows exactly what they want to do and do it, but keep the people in check by saying, “Everybody is equal here!” One great book to read about this topic is Animal Farm, which is about instant, total power and how those who take advantage of that are corrupted. So, now we have established that China is totalitarian in its own way, we can move onto Iraq. This is the example of totalitarianism that is just pure evil. Iraq wasn’t totalitarian before one man: Saddam Hussein. In his idea of the perfect country, he had complete control and surveillance over his country’s population. Those who disagreed with his ways were kidnapped then tortured and brutally beheaded in public. Not so fun fact: Hussein was the first leader of all time who allowed the use of bio-weapons against his own populace. One man, al-Shaikh Yahya, tried to resist this, but he was arrested and sent to prison. I will not repeat what happened to him, but if you really want to know, click this link. It goes into greater detail than I wish to about all his crimes, including the methods of torture he favoured All media is owned by him, and some is fabricated by him. He also committed genocide multiple times against ethnic or religious groups he didn’t agree with, such as the Kurdish, Shi’a and Kuwaiti peoples. However, in 2003, he was hanged because the people couldn’t bear his life. There are few people in the world that I wish dead, but the world is definitely a better place without this evil man. The country isn’t back to normal yet, but without another Saddam Hussein, they will get there in the future. The moral of this story is that when you do terrible things, people don’t forget and they definitely don’t forgive. To avoid this sort of backlash, don’t do the disgusting things to start with.
